title: Ticket #2102: The condor_kbdd loses communication with the startd on Windows
description:
Under Windows the condor_kbdd daemon must be started as a standalone daemon, once for every logged in user. This causes some issues with using condor_kbdd on Windows that can result in keyboard idle times not being reset and START/SUSPEND/RESUME/PREEMPT policies that rely on keyboard idle time numbers to fail (or at least think that there's always no keyboard activity on the machine).

There are two situations where I have found this problem to occur:

  1. If a machine is suspend, when resuming, the condor_startd will almost always end up listening on a different port than what it used pre-suspension. In this case the condor_kbdd instances on the machine will continue to attempt communication with the startd on the old port and all keyboard activity will fail to be reported from this point on.

  2. If the condor daemons controlled by the condor_master on the machine are restarted a similar situation with the condor_startd listening on a new port will occur.

In both cases the problem seems be caused by the fact that the condor_kbdd instances on the machine are not DAEMON_LIST daemons and therefore aren't notified that they should re-config (or restart) themselves in concert with the other Condor daemons who are on DAEMON_LIST and controlled by condor_master on the machine.

The condor_kbdd daemon doesn't seem to be smart enough to recognize that, if it can't talk to a condor_startd repeatedly, it should perhaps try re-reading its configuration because maybe the condor_startd listen port has changed on the machine.

You have to go through some pains to kick the condor_kbdd instances when this happens. A normal "condor_status -reconfig -full" is insufficient because the condor_master won't send the reconfig signal to the user-run condor_kbdd daemons. You have to figure out their listen ports and IP addresses by parsing the KbdLog file and send explicit reconfig commands using the "-addr <ip:port>" approach. That's less than ideal and also difficult to do in any way that keeps the condor_kbdd instances in good lockstep with the condor_startd on any machine.

I've encountered this problem using Condor 7.4.4 and 7.6.0 on Windows XP and Windows 7.
remarks:
2011-May-01 16:03:32 by ichesal:
I was playing around with a fix to this a bit today and it turns out sending an explicit reconfig to the condor_kbdd daemon using the sinful string doesn't get it to recognize that the startd's listen port has changed.

And trying to condor_restart it using the sinful string gets you:

05/01 17:01:19 Received TCP command 453 (UNREGISTERED COMMAND!) from <172.16.114.128:4494>

So it looks like the only solution is to kill, and then restart all condor_kbdd instances running on a machine.

Urg.

Not fun.

2011-May-02 16:33:06 by ziliang:
Is this also happening when KBDD is part of DAEMON_LIST?

2011-May-03 09:43:03 by ichesal:
Lets meet and talk about this while I'm in WI this week for Condor Week. Running with KBDD in the daemon list means condor_kbdd doesn't see keyboard activity in Windows, which is why it's started as a non-Condor daemon in this case.

2011-May-04 15:43:21 by ichesal:
Just an update with the stuff I just showed you.

I added KBDD to the DAEMON_LIST and started Condor. Then I started condor_kbdd as me (Administrator) so it was all running as requested. The startd was listening on <172.16.114.128:4902>. And the kbdd daemon log showed the kbdd reporting in to the startd on the correct port.

I did a condor_restart against the startd and it switched to port <172.16.114.128:4983>.

Unfortunately the kbdd daemons didn't see this change and continued to try to report in to the old port.

I tried both a condor_reconfig -subsys KBDD and a condor_restart -subsys KBDD and there was no change in the port the kbdd was reporting to -- it was still using the old, wrong startd port.

Logging off, logging back in to the machine fixes the problem and everything lines up again.

2011-May-11 14:26:09 by ziliang:
I believe this is fixed. I started up Condor, suspended, resumed, and saw that the KBDD was using the new address.

2011-May-11 14:39:23 by johnkn:
fixing bugs by removing code. I like it.

2011-May-11 19:06:05 by ziliang:
Ian reports success. Good enough for me.
